'}, {'number': 18, 'created': '2015-08-28 16:22:52.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/5c409a2cb7c822747cb4691118b67e65039ade20', 'message': 'Amphora Flows and Service Drivers for Active Standby

This patch implements the Active/Standby blueprint in
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/activepassiveamphora

The following paragraphs describes the main changes:

1. Add new flows and subflows to create M amphorae. The controller worker
parses the loadbalancer_topology configuration. If the oadbalancer_topology
value is ACTIVE_STANDBY, the controller invokes a new flow independent from the
SINGLE topology case, which is left untouched. The new flow uses conditional
taskflows to check for spare amphorae at runtime. This removes the need for the
exception workaround we earlier had. The controller creates the amphorae in
parallel using an unordered flow. A new database task alter an amphora role as
either MASTER or BACKUP and assigns a VRRP priority to each amphora. After the
amphorae are created, the controller invokes a separate flow for post amphora
configuration including plug_vip methods, vrrp configuration upload, and
keepalived service start.

2. New data models that include a new table for VRRP group configuration per
loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and listener tables to
support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup table hides
authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy were introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisments, and
enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Change-Id: Ic4e04594e114ba682088d68d5f1af3f8f376db83
'}, {'number': 19, 'created': '2015-08-28 16:24:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/d7a0ad963233f742d2d34da2fdf45b44900616e8', 'message': 'Amphora Flows and Service Drivers for Active Standby

This patch implements the Active/Standby blueprint in
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/activepassiveamphora

The following paragraphs describe the main changes:

1. Add new flows and subflows to create M amphorae. The controller worker
parses the loadbalancer_topology configuration. If the oadbalancer_topology
value is ACTIVE_STANDBY, the controller invokes a new flow independent from the
SINGLE topology case, which is left untouched. The new flow uses conditional
taskflows to check for spare amphorae at runtime. This removes the need for the
exception workaround we earlier had. The controller creates the amphorae in
parallel using an unordered flow. A new database task alter an amphora role as
either MASTER or BACKUP and assigns a VRRP priority to each amphora. After the
amphorae are created, the controller invokes a separate flow for post amphora
configuration including plug_vip methods, vrrp configuration upload, and
keepalived service start.

2. New data models that include a new table for VRRP group configuration per
loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and listener tables to
support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup table hides
authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy were introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisments, and
enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Change-Id: Ic4e04594e114ba682088d68d5f1af3f8f376db83

creates the amphorae in parallel using an unordered flow. A new database task
alter an amphora role as either MASTER or BACKUP and assigns a VRRP priority to
each amphora. After the amphorae are created, the controller invokes a separate
flow for post amphora configuration including plug_vip methods, vrrp
configuration upload, and keepalived service start.

2. The patch introduces new data models that include a new table for VRRP group
configuration per loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and
listener tables to support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup
table hides authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP
capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy were introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisments, and
enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint activepassiveamphora

configuration per loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and
listener tables to support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup
table hides authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP
capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy were introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisements,
and enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Note: Updates to the failover flow to support active/standby will come in
a dependent patch.

Co-Authored-By: Sherif Abdelwahab <sherif.abdelwahab@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>

controller worker parses the loadbalancer_topology configuration. If the

'}, {'number': 50, 'created': '2015-12-03 01:51:37.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/octavia/commit/ac9a13a0cc777aa4cf9ad03fb07d70f9d3257a74', 'message': 'Amphora Flows and Drivers for Active Standby

This patch implements the Active/Standby blueprint in
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/activepassiveamphora

The following points describe the main changes:

1. The patch introduces new flows and subflows to create M amphorae. The
controller worker parses the loadbalancer_topology configuration. If the
loadbalancer_topology value is ACTIVE_STANDBY, the controller invokes a new flow
independent from the SINGLE topology case, which is left untouched. The new
flow uses conditional taskflows to check for spare amphorae at runtime. This
removes the need for the exception workaround we earlier had. The controller
creates the amphorae in parallel using an unordered flow. A new database task
alter an amphora role as either MASTER or BACKUP and assigns a VRRP priority to
each amphora. After the amphorae are created, the controller invokes a separate
flow for post amphora configuration including plug_vip methods, vrrp
configuration upload, and keepalived service start.

2. The patch introduces new data models that include a new table for VRRP group
configuration per loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and
listener tables to support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup
table hides authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP
capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS accounting for ports in use.

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy was introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisements,
and enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Note: Updates to the failover flow to support active/standby will come in
a dependent patch.

Co-Authored-By: Sherif Abdelwahab <sherif.abdelwahab@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint activepassiveamphora
Depends-On: Ifdf20378b26cdd13e0a3ff87cec8990fe89c0661
Change-Id: Ic4e04594e114ba682088d68d5f1af3f8f376db83

commit_message:
Amphora Flows and Drivers for Active Standby

This patch implements the Active/Standby blueprint in
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/octavia/+spec/activepassiveamphora

The following points describe the main changes:

1. The patch introduces new flows and subflows to create M amphorae. The
controller worker parses the loadbalancer_topology configuration. If the
loadbalancer_topology value is ACTIVE_STANDBY, the controller invokes a new flow
independent from the SINGLE topology case, which is left untouched. The new
flow uses conditional taskflows to check for spare amphorae at runtime. This
removes the need for the exception workaround we earlier had. The controller
creates the amphorae in parallel using an unordered flow. A new database task
alter an amphora role as either MASTER or BACKUP and assigns a VRRP priority to
each amphora. After the amphorae are created, the controller invokes a separate
flow for post amphora configuration including plug_vip methods, vrrp
configuration upload, and keepalived service start.

2. The patch introduces new data models that include a new table for VRRP group
configuration per loadbalancer, and update the amphora, loadbalancer, and
listener tables to support the new active/standby capability. The VRRPGroup
table hides authentication data, and makes future extensions of VRRP
capabilities easy.

3. This patch updates the existing Haproxy configuration templates  to include
peer synchronization. In case of ACTIVE_STANDBY configuration, the jinja
configuration renders the peer section in the Haproxy configuration and assigns
short names to the amphorae as listener peers. As listeners implies different
Haproxy process, each listener synchronizes on a different port evaluated as
BASE_PORT (1024) + NUMBER_OF_LISTENERS accounting for ports in use.

4. This patch introduces a new Jinja configuration templater and a REST driver
for Keepalived (developed as a Mixin). By default, Keepalived runs "all" check
scripts found in a predefined directory. The keepalived driver is a Mixin that
can be plugged in other services' drivers. It is the responsibility of these
services drivers to introduce their own check scripts. In this patch a
lightweight check script for Haproxy was introduced along with changes in the
amphora agent installation script.

5. The VRRP requires enabling protocol 112 for Master/Backup advertisements,
and enabling protocol 51 for authentication header. This patch enables these
protocols as needed in the loadbalancer security group.

Note: Updates to the failover flow to support active/standby will come in
a dependent patch.
Note: The amphora-agent is pinned to this patch in this patch set.  This
is required so the scenario tests will pass.  It will be removed in a
follow up patch.

Co-Authored-By: Sherif Abdelwahab <sherif.abdelwahab@hp.com>
Co-Authored-By: Michael Johnson <johnsomor@gmail.com>
Implements: blueprint activepassiveamphora
Depends-On: Ifdf20378b26cdd13e0a3ff87cec8990fe89c0661
Change-Id: Ic4e04594e114ba682088d68d5f1af3f8f376db83
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/octavia refs/changes/52/206252/25 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # # Load balancer topology options are SINGLE, ACTIVE_STANDBY # loadbalancer_topology = ACTIVE_STANDBY

commit_message:
Revert "Don't initialize SSHManager while reporting results"

The bug was fixed by Ifd3ae4db66f37992ff8f956491882915f8fc1ec3
so removing temporary workaround.

This reverts commit 2925f0ac2f22319e44badf67b5581b17d8664b07.

Change-Id: I2d6e0c812c17d6bc0b0469c5683a7802fd7b0f7d
Related-bug: #1528491
(cherry picked from commit 9a99555b4adcdb5804d1a73d5a67ee20304c329e)

commit_message:
Note Pacemaker resource agents for RabbitMQ

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ha-guide refs/changes/88/261588/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. note:: As another option to make RabbitMQ highly available, RabbitMQ contains the OCF scripts for the Pacemaker cluster resource agents since version 3.5.7. It provides the active/active RabbitMQ cluster with mirrored queues. For more information, see `Auto-configuration of a cluster with a Pacemaker <http://www.rabbitmq.com/pacemaker.html>`_.

commit_message:
Updates consistency group for ibm svc driver

The changes are:
1. ability to modify a consistecy group (update_consistencygroup)
2. ability to create a consistency group from a cgsnapshot or from
   another consistency group (create_consistencygroup_from_src)

DocImpact
Change-Id: Ibdf60ca50d6ee2d25ed51b8f0adbb64ff2a3d17c
Implements: bp ibm-storwize-cg-updates
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/66/259766/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: def _create_consistencegroup(self, **kwargs): cg = self._create_consistencygroup_in_db(**kwargs) model_update = self.driver.create_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cg) self.assertEqual('available', model_update['status'], "CG created failed") return cg def _create_cgsnapshot(self, cg_id, **kwargs): cg_snapshot = self._create_cgsnapshot_in_db(cg_id, **kwargs) model_update, snapshots = \ (self.driver.create_cgsnapshot(self.ctxt, cg_snapshot, [])) self.assertEqual('available', model_update['status'], "CGSnapshot created failed") for snapshot in snapshots: self.assertEqual('available', snapshot['status']) snapshots = \ self.db.snapshot_get_all_for_cgsnapshot(self.ctxt.elevated(), cg_snapshot['id']) return cg_snapshot, snapshots def test_storwize_consistency_group_from_src_invalid(self): # Invalid input case for create cg from src cg_type = self._create_consistency_group_volume_type() self.ctxt.user_id = 'fake_user_id' self.ctxt.project_id = 'fake_project_id' # create cg in db cg = self._create_consistencygroup_in_db(volume_type_id=cg_type['id']) # create volumes in db vol1 = testutils.create_volume(self.ctxt, volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=cg['id']) vol2 = testutils.create_volume(self.ctxt, volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=cg['id']) volumes = [vol1, vol2] source_cg = self._create_consistencegroup(volume_type_id=cg_type['id']) # Add volumes to source CG src_vol1 = self._create_volume(volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=source_cg['id']) src_vol2 = self._create_volume(volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=source_cg['id']) source_vols = [src_vol1, src_vol2] cgsnapshot, snapshots = self._create_cgsnapshot(source_cg['id']) # Create cg from src with null input self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src, self.ctxt, cg, volumes, None, None, None, None) # Create cg from src with source_cg and empty source_vols self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src, self.ctxt, cg, volumes, None, None, source_cg, None) # Create cg from src with source_vols and empty source_cg self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src, self.ctxt, cg, volumes, None, None, None, source_vols) # Create cg from src with cgsnapshot and empty snapshots self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src, self.ctxt, cg, volumes, cgsnapshot, None, None, None) # Create cg from src with snapshots and empty cgsnapshot self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src, self.ctxt, cg, volumes, None, snapshots, None, None) model_update = self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cg, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for volume in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', volume['status']) model_update = \ self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, source_cg, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for volume in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', volume['status']) model_update = \ self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cgsnapshot, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for volume in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', volume['status']) def test_storwize_consistency_group_from_src(self): # Invalid input case for create cg from src cg_type = self._create_consistency_group_volume_type() self.ctxt.user_id = 'fake_user_id' self.ctxt.project_id = 'fake_project_id' # Create cg in db cg = self._create_consistencygroup_in_db(volume_type_id=cg_type['id']) # Create volumes in db testutils.create_volume(self.ctxt, volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=cg['id']) testutils.create_volume(self.ctxt, volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=cg['id']) volumes = \ self.db.volume_get_all_by_group(self.ctxt.elevated(), cg['id']) # Create source CG source_cg = self._create_consistencegroup(volume_type_id=cg_type['id']) # Add volumes to source CG self._create_volume(volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=source_cg['id']) self._create_volume(volume_type_id=cg_type['id'], consistencygroup_id=source_cg['id']) source_vols = self.db.volume_get_all_by_group( self.ctxt.elevated(), source_cg['id']) # Create cgsnapshot cgsnapshot, snapshots = self._create_cgsnapshot(source_cg['id']) # Create cg from source cg model_update, volumes_model_update = ( self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src(self.ctxt, cg, volumes, None, None, source_cg, source_vols)) self.assertEqual('available', model_update['status'], "CG create from src created failed") for each_vol in volumes_model_update: self.assertEqual('available', each_vol['status']) model_update = self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cg, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for each_vol in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', each_vol['status']) # Create cg from cg snapshot model_update, volumes_model_update = ( self.driver.create_consistencygroup_from_src(self.ctxt, cg, volumes, cgsnapshot, snapshots, None, None)) self.assertEqual('available', model_update['status'], "CG create from src created failed") for each_vol in volumes: self.assertEqual('available', each_vol['status']) model_update = self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cg, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for each_vol in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', each_vol['status']) model_update = self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, cgsnapshot, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for volume in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', volume['status']) model_update = self.driver.delete_consistencygroup(self.ctxt, source_cg, []) self.assertEqual('deleted', model_update[0]['status']) for each_vol in model_update[1]: self.assertEqual('deleted', each_vol['status'])

commit_message:
Cap setuptools for avoiding gate issue

New setuptools(19.2) has been released 25/Dec and Tempest gate starts to
be broken on the kilo stable branch.

Closes-Bug: #1530026
Change-Id: I30e0570c89cbe75934df9dbdad3bbd8cea208631

commit_message:
Horizon support for Service Function Chaining

This patch implements horizon CRUD support for below resources.
- Flow Classifier
- Port Pair
- Port Pair Group
- Port Chain

commit_message:
Set default mtu value for l2 patch

We did not set mtu for ovs2lnx and lnx2lnx patches by default, but as it is
not HW it is better to have not fragmentation there at all

Change-Id: I2420b0122b7fe14c60146bf9b42f7f1bc409c2b7
Related-bug: #1529098

commit_message:
LOG.warn -> LOG.warning

Python 3 deprecated the logger.warn method, see:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.warning
so we prefer to use warning to avoid DeprecationWarning.

In addition to this there will be a hacking rule to prevent this
(https://review.openstack.org/#/c/262257/)

TrivialFix

Change-Id: Ic6802778eeeb9c48e5780de46dcf1f3d272e163b

commit_message:
switch to f23

f21 is eol, and looking at a recent failure, it's really not fixable,
as we're asking for packages it doesn't have. We should move forward
full speed on f23 and fix what issues are found there.

In future we should expect to rotate to the new fedora within a couple
months of it being out, doing the 2 fedora jump puts us in binds like
this where we have jobs running on non supported distros.

Depends-On: I3f1ffeb6de3b1f952292a144efab9554f7f99a5f

Change-Id: I15881647ebf63e22b62bd20a4bcaf2cd5c61ef55

commit_message:
extract common ansible options

all ansible commands had some common options (-f , -i). Instead of
specifying them on every command, instead specify them in a global
config file. This makes less chance of a copy / paste error in the
future, and makes the code a bit easier to read.

Also extract the ansible setup and configure to a dedicated function,
as this was getting long enough it's a bit simpler to think about as a
functional block.

Change-Id: Id1f0ecb46df747985b53995f84468fe9fcb40a41
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack-gate refs/changes/94/202494/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: function install_ansible { # Install and configure ansible sudo -H pip install virtualenv virtualenv /tmp/ansible /tmp/ansible/bin/pip install ansible export ANSIBLE=/tmp/ansible/bin/ansible # Write inventory file with groupings local ansible_inventory=$WORKSPACE/inventory local counter=1 echo "[primary]" > "$ansible_inventory" echo "localhost ansible_connection=local host_counter=$counter" >> "$ansible_inventory" echo "[subnodes]" >> "$ansible_inventory" SUBNODES=$(cat /etc/nodepool/sub_nodes_private) for SUBNODE in $SUBNODES ; do let counter=counter+1 echo "$SUBNODE host_counter=$COUNTER" >> "$ansible_inventory" done # options that will be common across all ansible commands should # just go into the config file, less chance that they accidentally # get miscopied / mistyped in a command. echo "inventory = $ansible_inventory" | sudo tee /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg # note, fork=5 is the default, we probably don't need to set it. echo "fork = 5" | sudo tee -a /etc/ansible/ansible.cfg }

commit_message:
Add consts to fuelmenu

logfiles, config files, version files, and deployment
modes are now stored as constant values.

Added is_(pre|post)_deployment methods to simplify
logic when looking up deployment mode.

Change-Id: I114e0a82fa07ff3bdcf0d0c4fb37d94d05acd923
Closes-Bug: #1514382

commit_message:
Set selinux to permissive in Vagrant

Selinux is preventing to write on mounted volumes. Let's set it to
permissive in Vagrant box provisioning.

Change-Id: If8ea57f242166eb6f4ef618639d4ab672e5098d3
Closes-Bug: #1530766
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/38/263138/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Set selinux to permissive sed -i -r "s,^SELINUX=.+$,SELINUX=permissive," /etc/selinux/config setenforce permissive

commit_message:
Rollback of live-migration fails with the NFS driver

This error occurs when fail to live migrate before
destination host attach to the NFS server.
We should consider whether destination host has mounted to
NFS server or not when executing rollback of live-migration.

Closes-Bug: #1500337
Change-Id: Id6d0bfead0557e1dfe4aeee56a7d85adaf38549a

"Python 3.3 support is being dropped since OpenStack Liberty."
written in following URL.
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

And already the infra team and the oslo team are dropping py33

Since we rely on oslo for a lot of our work, and depend on infra

commit_message:
Drop py33 support

"Python 3.3 support is being dropped since OpenStack Liberty."
written in following URL.
https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Python3

And already the infra team and the oslo team are dropping py33
support from their projects.

Since we rely on oslo for a lot of our work, and depend on infra
for our CI, we should drop py33 support too.

Change-Id: I655bd6ea2144c7d00bc4d1f4373ecb1639ec2966
Closes-Bug: #1526170
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-solumclient refs/changes/86/257786/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py27,py34,pypy,pep8

added_lines: # Copyright 2015 Mirantis, Inc. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from proboscis import test from fuelweb_test import settings from fuelweb_test.helpers.decorators import log_snapshot_after_test from fuelweb_test.tests.base_test_case import SetupEnvironment from fuelweb_test.tests.base_test_case import TestBasic @test(groups=["mixed_os_components", "additional_components"]) class MixedComponents(TestBasic): """MixedComponents""" # TODO documentation @test(depends_on=[SetupEnvironment.prepare_slaves_9], groups=["mixed_components_murano_sahara_ceilometer"]) @log_snapshot_after_test def mixed_components_murano_sahara_ceilometer(self): """Deployment with 3 controllers, NeutronTUN, with Murano, Sahara and Ceilometer Scenario: 1. Create new environment 2. Choose Neutron + TUN, Cinder 3. Enable Sahara, Murano and Ceilometer 4. Add 3 controller, 1 compute, 1 cinder and 3 mongo nodes 5. Verify networks 6. Deploy the environment 7. Verify networks 8. Run OSTF tests Duration: 300 min Snapshot: mixed_components_murano_sahara_ceilometer """ self.env.revert_snapshot('ready_with_9_slaves') data = { 'murano': True, 'sahara': True, 'ceilometer': True, 'tenant': 'mixedcomponents', 'user': 'mixedcomponents', 'password': 'mixedcomponents', "net_provider": 'neutron', "net_segment_type": settings.NEUTRON_SEGMENT['tun'], } self.show_step(1) self.show_step(2) self.show_step(3) cluster_id = self.fuel_web.create_cluster( name=self.__class__.__name__, settings=data ) self.show_step(4) self.fuel_web.update_nodes( cluster_id, { 'slave-01': ['controller'], 'slave-02': ['controller'], 'slave-03': ['controller'], 'slave-04': ['compute'], 'slave-05': ['cinder'], 'slave-06': ['mongo'], 'slave-07': ['mongo'], 'slave-08': ['mongo'] } ) self.show_step(5) self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.show_step(6) self.fuel_web.deploy_cluster_wait(cluster_id) self.show_step(7) self.fuel_web.verify_network(cluster_id) self.show_step(8) self.fuel_web.run_ostf(cluster_id, test_sets=['smoke', 'sanity', 'ha', 'tests_platform']) self.env.make_snapshot('mixed_components_murano_sahara_ceilometer')

commit_message:
Update ramdisk callback documentation

Change-Id: If4291e95b2ab1e27659b69e0f00121a3bd902356
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-inspector refs/changes/60/260960/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Optionally the following keys might be provided: * ``inventory`` full hardware inventory from the ironic-python-agent (will be required in the future). Required for root device hints support. * ``root_disk`` default deployment root disk as calculated by the ironic-python-agent algorithm. Will be required in the future. * ``error`` error happened during ramdisk run, interpreted by ``ramdisk_error`` plugin. * ``logs`` base64-encoded logs from the ramdisk. * ``block_devices`` block devices information for the ``raid_device`` plugin, dictionary with one key: ``serials`` list of serial numbers of block devices. This is deprecated and only supported for backward compatibility. Full ``inventory`` should be provided instead. This list highly depends on enabled plugins, provided above are expected keys for the default set of plugins. See :ref:`plugins` for details.
deleted_lines: * ``error`` optional error happened during ramdisk run, interpreted by ``ramdisk_error`` plugin * ``logs`` optional base64-encoded logs from the ramdisk * ``block_devices`` optional block devices information for ``root_device_hint`` plugin, dictionary with keys: * ``serials`` list of serial numbers of block devices. This list highly depends on enabled plugins, provided above are expected keys for the default set of plugins. See :ref:`plugins` for details.

When run on a clean system, bower will ask (once) whether it is

'}]
commit_message:
Added config-interactive flag

When run on a clean system, bower will ask (once) whether it is
permitted to report usage statistics. This requires user
interaction, and can cause builds to freeze. This patch adds the
appropriate commandline flag that tells bower that it should not
do this.

Change-Id: Ief2ab94abe237ccd8d38a73b308b91885ccd4129
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ironic-webclient refs/changes/22/254322/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: "postinstall": "bower install --config.interactive=false",

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-16 14:18:53.000000000', 'files': ['reference/projects.yaml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/186ba56c0378a353c60debc2584b0c6e5ea8c58d', 'message': 'Change release model to cycle-with-intermediary

Currently freezer uses an indipendent release model.
This is not suitable anymore as are aligning to

Change-Id: I793e297324ed6d8a3bcea8413c651b28807f635b
'}]
commit_message:
Change release model to cycle-with-intermediary

Currently freezer uses an indipendent release model.
This is not suitable anymore as are aligning to
the other Openstack projects and having branches managed
by the stable maintenance team.

Change-Id: I793e297324ed6d8a3bcea8413c651b28807f635b

stable release.

commit_message:
Fix 'cannot access' error with Redis restore

When restoring a Redis instance on Ubuntu 12.04, there has an error
in guestagent log:
"cannot access `/var/lib/redis/dump.rdb': No such file or directory"

This is because on a new instance, this file may or may not exist.
Also changed the logic around cleaning up the file before restoring the
backup in redis_impl.py as it was treating the 'restore' location as
a directory, instead of as a file.

Fixes Bug: #1528244

Change-Id: I422d68343867638c0ea6272266a21c6e73349de7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/trove refs/changes/39/260039/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Fix issue with flake8 check and full paths

Currently hacking check_explicit_underscore_import is dependent
on a relative file path. A call of "flake8 ." works fine but
"flake8 $PWD" doesn't which shouldn't be any difference.

Change-Id: I7d40bbb771f96d28db38db69939de5e5993f3e9b
Closes-bug: #1530460

commit_message:
Use oslo_config IPOpt support

IPOpt is supported in new version of oslo_config, so modify it.

And in the nova/tests/unit/virt/libvirt/test_driver.py, the fakeip
does not fit the IP format. Modify it too.

Change-Id: I31875d94f75e575208fa3cc4f8756f1e23d423e0

commit_message:
use keystoneclient exceptions instead of oslo-incubator code

depending on any oslo-incubator code from another project is
dangerous. keystoneclient makes its exceptions public and it's
not recommended to use any code from
keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient since it's maintained
by oslo-incubator.

Change-Id: I22b7977f943abac9418342d4fd3d2b996d717e91
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-watcherclient refs/changes/05/261805/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: from keystoneclient.openstack.common.apiclient import exceptions as ks_exc

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-30 21:27:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/project-config/commit/9ebd17657db29128c1c41d45e3480bbf07b87bf2', 'message': 'New Project - ekko

way that is scallable by using object-storage for the backend. The
backup itself is enabled by a new feature in QEMU 2.4 that allows for
changed block tracking and incremental backups of running VMs.

A common feature I have seen requested throughout the community is
true block-based backups of VMs. I have been working on a way to solve
the scalability issue of backups for a while [1] and now that QEMU has
officially released this feature we can bring backup to OpenStack in a
way that is as scallable as OpenStack itself using Swift as a backend.

This would be different than a nova snapshot because that is not a
true backup. That does not allow for the space savings of incremental
backups nor compression or encryption which are requirements for a
good backup in my experience.

Future goals would including bringing this to other hypervisors since
Hyper-V and VMWare both support CBT and incremental backups of running
VMs. As well as potentially backing up Cinder volumes in a similiar
fashion.

[1] https://github.com/SamYaple/osdk

commit_message:
New Project - ekko

ekko is a project that will bring block-based backup to OpenStack in a
way that is scallable by using object-storage for the backend. The
backup itself is enabled by a new feature in QEMU 2.4 that allows for
changed block tracking and incremental backups of running VMs.

A common feature I have seen requested throughout the community is
true block-based backups of VMs. I have been working on a way to solve
the scalability issue of backups for a while [1] and now that QEMU has
officially released this feature we can bring backup to OpenStack in a
way that is as scallable as OpenStack itself using Swift as a backend.

This would be different than a nova snapshot because that is not a
true backup. That does not allow for the space savings of incremental
backups nor compression or encryption which are requirements for a
good backup in my experience.

Future goals would including bringing this to other hypervisors since
Hyper-V and VMWare both support CBT and incremental backups of running
VMs. As well as potentially backing up Cinder volumes in a similiar
fashion.

[1] https://github.com/SamYaple/osdk

Add the missing import packages and format the log messages
Move i18n to package(cloudkittyclient)

commit_message:
Magnum: Add new job to do mesos functional testing

Adds gate_hook to magnum jobs.
Adds new pipe line to do mesos functional testing, set it to non-voting
first.

Implements: blueprint mesos-functional-testing
Depend-On: I8ee53de4d34aa79d037901e599fc6409a7de2e72

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on
py34 we have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27.
This patch puts py34 first on the tox.ini list of envs to
avoid this problem to happen.

Change-Id: I7b8f5c27c1d1768f38869cf8c07792b9defb4186
Closes-bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/76/262876/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,pep8

commit_message:
[Docs] improve cli docs

 * add docstring for `rally-manage db recreate`.
 * updates `deprecated_args` to handle release and alternative arg.
 * rename `--verification` and `task` to `--uuid` in `rally verify use` and
   `rally task use`.(these arguments should have the same name across one
   category). The old names are deprecated.
 * rename destination of `--uuid`, `--uuid-1`, `uuid-2` arguments to
   `verification`, `verification1`, `verification2` for consistent with other
   destinations.
 * remove `required=False` attribute setting for task_id in `rally task use`.
 * fix attribute name in `default_from_global` for `report`

Change-Id: Ib2edb32443f59f8168ff124bddb77950881dcd5e

commit_message:
[Ironic] move ironic-compute to controller

Until Ironic cannot works with multiple nova-compute services, ironic-specific
nova-compute should runs in active/backup mode.

This change introdues CS resource for ironic's nova-compute on controller,
which replaces nova-computes on ironic's nodes.

Closes-bug: #1522361
Change-Id: Ibd021656cae1e5755db33d3c44ddc68f1940465a

commit_message:
Set default mtu value for l2 patch

We did not set mtu for ovs2lnx and lnx2lnx patches by default, but as it is
not HW it is better to have not fragmentation there at all.

Change-Id: I2420b0122b7fe14c60146bf9b42f7f1bc409c2b7
Related-bug: #1529098
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/fuel-library refs/changes/66/262766/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

deleted_lines: # Specify MTU value for patchcord. $mtu = undef,

commit_message:
Fix read/write permissions on ceph pool for backups

Cinder and Backup users should have read/write
permissions on ceph 'backups' pool. Update noop tests.

Change-Id: I8c05921dc52c3e6d4f7152d3f0e0c669790d0a44
Closes-bug: #1529257

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2015-12-30 14:14:39.000000000', 'files': ['tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/a6d905be62d8dcd87fc5ec5045983c20ad899e8a', 'message': 'Do not fail with Tox 2.3.1

Latest tox causes failures:
   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/tox/config.py", line 1140, in processcommand

(cherry picked from commit f59e6df23a430f0622215fec5bbbe18cfe7fee9c)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not fail with Tox 2.3.1

Latest tox causes failures:
   File "/usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/tox/config.py", line 1140, in processcommand
     argv = list(shlexer)
   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/shlex.py", line 269, in next
     token = self.get_token()
   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/shlex.py", line 96, in get_token
     raw = self.read_token()
   File "/usr/lib/python2.7/shlex.py", line 172, in read_token
     raise ValueError, "No closing quotation"
 ValueError: No closing quotation

This is caused by a backwards incompatible change in tox:
https://bitbucket.org/hpk42/tox/issues/181

Change-Id: Ic28c634cf806394cfa82b61cb45be60b8f40a61a
(cherry picked from commit f59e6df23a430f0622215fec5bbbe18cfe7fee9c)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/22/262522/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: -not \( -type d -name .?\* -prune \) \ -not \( -type d -name doc -prune \) \ -type f \ -not -name \*~ \ -wholename \*/inc/\* -or \ -wholename \*/lib/\* \ \) \
deleted_lines: -not \( -type d -name .?\* -prune \) \ # prune all 'dot' dirs -not \( -type d -name doc -prune \) \ # skip documentation -type f \ # only files -not -name \*~ \ # skip editors, readme, etc -wholename \*/inc/\* -or \ # /inc files and -wholename \*/lib/\* \ # /lib files are shell, but \) \ # have no extension

commit_message:
Use keystoneauth for session

The session from keystoneclient is being deprecated in favour of
keystoneauth1. This is a fairly low impact change with the APIs consumed
by clients unchanged.

In general all we need to do is change the session and auth plugin
loading components to come from the new loading module and the location
of a few modules.

Change-Id: I6c2c2bb2840576181128c63b5ac627794b5986d2

commit_message:
Fix log message translator issues

Instead of log.info("xxx") and log.warning("xxx"),
we should use log.info(_LI("xxx")) and log.warning(_LW("xxx"))

Closes-Bug:1530271

Change-Id: I95a408c8c3305fbd23804be89cd16008427279c6
Signed-off-by: Yang Li <yang.li@easystack.cn>

commit_message:
Fix comment about value returned

Function returns no value. The bug mentions it's only used locally, but there's
nothing that breaks the abstraction layer in the signature. Leaving it as
public.

Change-Id: Iadf902b82bf3c61fb5bc8402a192fa1929bb10c2
Closes-bug: 1491172

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could
not be determined" on py34 we have to run first the py34 env to, then, run
py27. This patch puts py34 first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this
problem to happen.

Change-Id: I088ae4e71bfa2e673743193751410693d533153b
Closes-bug: #1489059

commit_message:
Optimize action list method

We may don't need the 'context' key when dumping an action to a dict.
Doing this dump and then delete it before returning to client is insane.

Change-Id: I0cc0a6b23ad4a0be45a1375ddc27b1a74f5fbfe9

commit_message:
Make sort keys work for node-list and action-list

Some sort_keys columns are not shown in node-list,
and action-list, which will make sort keys meanless,
so add those keys into list fields.

Change-Id: I6dd93a9f9d01dad4b81b43792d88f8495c75264c
Closes-bug: #1528103

commit_message:
Fix cluster-policy-list command

After switching to SDK calls, we are not properly showing the name and
type of policies bound to a cluster. This patch fixes the problem.

Change-Id: Ie5549ba6c8c67943c0595469d9fc1d7094e6825b

commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could
not be determined" on py34 we have to run first the py34 env to, then, run
py27. This patch puts py34 first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this
problem to happen.

Change-Id: I94baade12db4b445e2f7879b1674c5d8e29fcccf
Closes-bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-dracclient refs/changes/95/260495/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,pep8,py27

commit_message:
Make policy name and type shown in cluster-policy-list

Currently policy name and type are not shown in cluster-policy-list
for wrong column names.

Change-Id: I4146be3ea9f31009945f64e3edb5ee2bfdb7fe60
Closes-bug: #1530773

commit_message:
Change LOG.warn to LOG.warning

Python 3 deprecated the logger.warn method, see:
https://docs.python.org/3/library/logging.html#logging.warning
so we prefer to use warning to avoid DeprecationWarning.

Change-Id: Ic7496d4dc765586e1bc79c3202b80c444443faf0
Closes-Bug: #1530742
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/90/263090/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: LOG.warning(_LW('Unrecognised child %s'), pid)

commit_message:
Update Galera Cluster documentation

Closes-Bug: #1414808
Co-Authored-By: KATO Tomoyuki <kato.tomoyuki@jp.fujitsu.com>
Change-Id: I90673dc233675dcd7872a9b55ffb13b6360e0574
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ha-guide refs/changes/10/143910/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines:
Galera Cluster for MySQL is a synchronous replication solution that can improve availability and performance of MySQL service. All Galera nodes are identical and fully representative of the cluster and allow unconstrained transparent mysql client access, acting as a single-distributed MySQL server. It provides: Transparent client connections, so that it is high compatible with existing applications; Synchronous data safety semantics — if a client received confirmation, transaction will be committed on every node; and, Automatic write conflict detection and resolution, so that nodes are always consistent. The primary focus is data consistency. The transactions are either applied on every node or not at all. So, the databases remain synchronized, provided that they were properly configured and synchronized at the start. The Galera Replication Plugin differs from the regular MySQL Replication by addressing several issues, including multi-master write conflicts, replication lag and slaves being out of sync with the master. In a typical instance of Galera Cluster, applications can write to any node in the cluster and transaction commits, (that is, RBR events), are then applied to all the servers through certification-based replication. Certification-based replication is an alternative approach to synchronous databases replication, using group communication and transaction ordering techniques. For more information on Galera Cluster for MySQL, see the Documentation.
Installation There are three versions of Galera Cluster for MySQL: the original Codership reference implementation; Percona XtraDB Cluster; and MariaDB Galera Cluster. For each database server, binary packages are available for Debian- and RPM-based distributions, or they can be built from source. System Requirements: Server hardware for a minimum of three nodes; 100 Mbps or better network connectivity; Linux or FreeBSD; Database server for MySQL, MariaDB, or Percona XtraDB; wsrep API patch for the database server; Galera Replication Plugin Preparing the Servers Before you begin the installation, there are a few tasks you need to perform to prepare the servers for Galera Cluster. You must perform the following steps for each node in your cluster. Disable SELinux If you have SELinux enabled, it may block mysqld from carrying out required operations. You must either disable SELinux or configure it to allow mysqld to run external programs and open listen sockets at unprivileged ports, (that is, things that an unprivileged user can do). To disable SELinux for mysqld, run the following command: # setmanage permissive -a mysqld_t SELinux now permits mysqld to function with Galera Cluster. Firewall Configuration Next, you will need to change the firewall settings, so that the nodes can communicate with each other and so that you can interact with them. For instance, if you use iptables, complete the following steps: # iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 3306 -j ACCEPT # iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 4444 -j ACCEPT # iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 4567 -j ACCEPT # iptables -I INPUT -p tcp --dport 4568 -j ACCEPT Once this is done, you need to save iptables. If your system uses init, run the following command: # service iptables save If instead your system uses systemd, run the following command: # systemctl iptables save Set the above firewall configurations on each node in the cluster. Disabling AppArmor By default, Ubuntu servers include AppArmor, which may prevent mysqld from opening additional ports or running scripts. You must disable AppArmor or configure it to allow mysqld to run external programs and open listen sockets at unprivileged ports. To disable AppArmor run the following commands on each node in the cluster: $ sudo ln -s /etc/apparmor.d/usr /etc/apparmor.d/disable/.sbin.mysqld $ sudo systemctl apparmor restart AppArmor now permits mysqld to function with Galera Cluster.
Galera Cluster for MySQL Installation Galera Cluster for MySQL is the reference implementation from Codership. Binary installation packages for Debian- and RPM-based Linux distributions are available for download from Launchpad.net. This tutorial omits MySQL authentication options for brevity. Installing Dependencies At this time, there is no repository available for installing and updating Galera Cluster for MySQL from your package manager. As such, you will need to install the dependencies separately. Install psmisc and the mysql Client. On Debian-based distributions, run the following command: # apt-get install psmisc \ mysql-client For RPM-based distributions, run the following command: # yum install psmisc \ mysql Go to MySQL Downloads and download the MySQL Shared Compatibility Libraries for your distribution. Then, install the MySQL Shared Compatibility Libraries. For Debian-based distributions, run the following command: # dpkg -i mysql-shared-compat-*.deb On RPM-based distributions, run the following command: # rpm -i MySQL-shared-compat-*.rpm The node is now ready to install Galera Cluster. Installing Galera Cluster There are two binary packages that make up Galera Cluster. The first is mysql-server-wsrep, which is a MySQL server that includes the wsrep API patch. The second is the Galera Replication Plugin. Go to MySQL patches by Codership and download the MySQL server package for your distribution. Then, go to Galera Replicator and download the Galera Replication plugin package for your distribution. Install the MySQL server and Galera Replication plugin. For Debian-based distributions, run the following command: # dpkg -i mysql-server-wsrep-*.deb \ galera-*.deb On RPM-based distributions, run the following command: # rpm -i MySQL-server-wsrep-*.rpm \ galera-*.rpm The Galera Cluster packages are now installed on your system.
MariaDB Galera Cluster Installation This is the MariaDB implementation of Galera Cluster for MySQL. Binary installation packages are available for Debian- and RPM-based distributions of Linux through the MariaDB repository. This tutorial omits MariaDB authentication options for brevity. Enabling the MariaDB Repository Installing MariaDB Galera Cluster through your package manager requires that you first enable the MariaDB repository on your system. There are two different ways to do this, depending on which Linux distribution you use. Enabling the Debian Repository The procedure for enabling the MariaDB repository for Debian-based distributions requires that you first install Software Properties. The package names may vary depending on your distribution. On Debian, run the following command: # apt-get install python-software-properties If you use Ubuntu, or a distribution that derives from Ubuntu, run this command instead: $ sudo apt-get install software-properties-common In the event that you use a different Debian-based distribution and neither of these commands works, consult your distribution's package listings. Once you have Software Properties installed, you can enable the MariaDB repository. Add the GnuPG key for the MariaDB repository to your server. # apt-key adv --recv-keys --keyserver \ keyserver.ubuntu.com 0xcbcb082a1bb943db Add the MariaDB repository to your sources list. # add-apt-repository 'deb http://mirror.jmu.edu/pub/mariadb/repo/version/distro release main For the repository address, make the following changes: version indicates the version number of MariaDB you want to use. For example, 5.6. distro indicates the name of your Linux distribution. For example, ubuntu. release indicates the release codename of the distribution you are using. For example, wheezy. In the event that you do not know which codename release you have installed on your server, you can find out using the following command: $ lsb_release -a No LSB modules are available. Distributor ID: Ubuntu Description: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS Release: 14.04 Codename: trusty In the example, for an Ubuntu 14.04 server, you would use the codename trusty from the output. Update the local cache. # apt-get update Packages in the MariaDB repository are now available for installation through apt-get. Enabling the RPM Repository For RPM-based distributions, you can enable the MariaDB repository by adding a .repo file to the /etc/yum.repos.d/ directory. Create the following file: # vim /etc/yum.repos.d/MariaDB.repo # MariaDB Repository List [mariadb] name = MariaDB baseurl = http://yum.mariadb.org/version/package gpgkey = https://yum.mariadb.org/RPM-GPG-KEY-MariaDB gpgcheck = 1 For the baseurl, make the following changes: version indicates the version of MariaDB that you want to use. For example, 5.6. package indicates the package name for your server. For example, rhel6-amd64 for a server that runs Red Hat Enterprise Linux 6 on 64-bit architecture. Packages in the MariaDB repository are now available for installation on your server through yum. For more information on the repository, package names or available mirrors, please consult the MariaDB Repository Configuration Tool. Installing MariaDB Galera Cluster There are three packages involved in the installation of MariaDB Galera Cluster: the MariaDB client, a command line tool for accessing the database; a build of the MariaDB server that includes the wsrep API patch; and the Galera Replication plugin. For Debian-based distributions, run the following command: # apt-get install mariadb-client \ mariadb-galera-server \ galera For RPM-based distributions, run the following command: # yum install MariaDB-client \ MariaDB-Galera-server \ galera MariaDB Galera Cluster is now installed on your server.
Percona XtraDB Cluster Installation This is the Percona XtraDB implementation of Galera Cluster for MySQL. Binary installation packages are available for Debian- and RPM-based distributions of Linux through the Percona repository. This tutorial omits Percona XtraDB authentication options for brevity. Enabling the Percona Repository Installing Percona XtraDB Cluster through your package anager requires that you first enable the Percona repository on your system. There are two different ways to do this, depending on which Linux distribution you use. Enabling the Debian Repository The procedure for enabling the Percona repository for Debian-based distributions requires that you first install Software Properties. The package names many vary depending on your distribution. On Debian, run the following command: # apt-get install python-software-properties If you use Ubuntu or a distribution that derives from Ubuntu, run this command instead: $ sudo apt-get install software-properties common Once you have Software Properties installed, you can enable the Percona repository. Add the GNuPG key for the Percona repository to your server. # apt-key adv --recv-keys --keyserver \ keyserver.ubuntu.com 1C4CBDCDCD2EFD2A Add the Percona repository to your sources list. # add-apt-repository 'deb http://repo.percona.com/apt release main For the repository address, make the following change: release indicates the release codename for the distribution you are using. For example, wheezy. In th event that you do not know which release codename you have installed on your server, you can find out using the following command: $ lsb_release -a No LSB modules are available. Distributor ID: Ubuntu Description: Ubuntu 14.04.1 LTS Release: 14.04 Codename: trusty In the example, for an Ubuntu 14.04 server, you would use the codename trusty from the output. Update the local cache. # apt-get update Packages in the Percona repository are now available for installation on your server through apt-get. Enabling the RPM Repository For RPM-based distributions, you can enable the Percona repository by adding a .repo file to the /etc/yum.repos.d/ directory. Install the Percona RPM repository: # yum install \ http://www.percona.com/downloads/percona-release/redhat/0.1-3/percona-release-0.1-3.noarch.rpm Packages in the Percona repository are now available for installation on your server through yum. Installing Percona XtraDB Cluster There are three packages involved in the installation of Percona XtraDB Cluster: the Percona XtraDB client, a command line tool for accessing the database; a build of the Percona XtraDB server that includes the wsrep API patch; and the Galera Replication plugin. For Debian-based distributions, run the following command: # apt-get install percona-xtradb-cluster For Ubuntu and distributions that derive from Ubuntu, you will need to specify the meta package. Run this command, instead: $ sudo apt-get install percona-xtradb-cluster \ percona-xtradb-cluster-galera For RPM-based distributions, run the following command: # yum install Percona-XtraDB-Cluster Percona XtraDB Cluster is now installed on your server.
Configuration When you have finished installing Galera Cluster on a server, you are ready to configure the database itself to serve as a node in the cluster. You will need to edit the MySQL configuration file. Using a simple text editor, edit the /etc/my.cnf file. It should look like this: [mysql] datadir=/var/lib/mysql socket=/var/lib/mysql/mysql.sock user=mysqlbind-address=0.0.0.0 default-storage-engine=innodbwsrep_provider=/usr/lib/libgalera_smm.so wsrep_cluster_name="example_cluster" wsrep_cluster_address="gcomm://IP.for.node1,IP.for.node2,IP.for.node3" wsrep_sst_method=rsync [mysql_safe] log-error=/var/log/mysqld.log pid-file=/var/run/mysqld/mysqld.pid wsrep_cluster_name You will need to edit value for this parameter to use whatever name you find convenient for your cluster. wsrep_cluster_address You will need to edit the values for this parameter to provide a comma separated list that provides the IP addresses for each node in your cluster. Do not change the innodb_autoinc_lock_mode parameter. In Galera Cluster, it can only be set to 2. When this parameter is set to traditional lock mode (a value of 0) or to consecutive lock mode (a value of 1 it can cause unresolved deadlocks and make the system unresponsive. When you finish making the changes, save the configuration file. Once you have Galera Cluster installed and configured on each node, you will be ready to start using the cluster.
Cluster Initialization When you have finished installing Galera Cluster and configuring the database for each node, you are ready to start the cluster. Before you begin, ensure that you have following ready: Galera Cluster installed and configured on at least three nodes. No firewalls between the nodes. SELinux and AppArmor disabled on each node, or running in permissive mode. Starting the Cluster Galera Cluster is initialized by starting the first mysql service with the --wsrep-new-cluster option. You may select any node to serve as the initial one. You then start each successive node as normal. They will connect to each other on their own. To begin, start mysqld on the initial node. If your system uses init, run the following command: # service mysql start --wsrep-new-cluster For systems that use systemd, run the following command: # systemctl mysql start --wsrep-new-cluster Next, you can check the cluster by retriving the cluster size, as contained in the wsrep_cluster_size status variable. Execute the following on node1: $ mysql -u root -e "SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_size';" +--------------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +--------------------+-------+ | wsrep_cluster_size | 1 | +--------------------+-------+ This indicates that Galera Cluster is running and that there is one node active in the cluster. Meaning, that the cluster has successfully initialized. The results given by the wsrep_cluster_size will increase with each successive node you add to the cluster. For each successive node, remember that the --wsrep-new-cluster parameter is only used to start the cluster when the entire cluster is down. If the cluster is still running, but the first node goes down, don't use this option to restart the first node. You are now ready to start the mysqld instance on your second node. For systems that use init, run the following command: # service mysql start For systems that use systemd, execute the following command: # systemctl mysql start When that is finished starting, check that everything is running correctly by checking the wsrep_cluster_size status variable on each node: $ mysql -u root -e "SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_size';" +--------------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +--------------------+-------+ | wsrep_cluster_size | 2 | +--------------------+-------+ $ mysql -u root -e "SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_size';" +--------------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +--------------------+-------+ | wsrep_cluster_size | 2 | +--------------------+-------+ The results here show that there are two nodes in the cluster. This also indicates that the databases on each node now function as a single distributed mysqld instance. The procedure for adding all other nodes to the cluster follows the same process as you use in adding the second node. For systems that use init, run the following command: # service mysql start For systems that use systemd, execute the following command: # systemctl mysql start As with previous instances, you can check that the node has successfully joined the cluster using the wsrep_cluster_size status variable. $ mysql -u root -e "SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_cluster_size';" +--------------------+-------+ | Variable_name | Value | +--------------------+-------+ | wsrep_cluster_size | 3 | +--------------------+-------+ If you get the same results, you were successful in starting the cluster. Testing the Cluster When you have the cluster up and running, you may want to test certain features to ensure that they are working properly or to better acquaint yourself with how the cluster operates. On any database client, verify that all nodes have connected to each other. SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep_%'; +---------------------------+------------+ | Variable_name | Value | +---------------------------+------------+ ... | wsrep_local_state_comment | Synced (6) | | wsrep_cluster_size | 3 | | wsrep_ready | ON | +---------------------------+------------+ wsrep_local_state_command Here, the value Synced indicates that the node is connected to the cluster and operational. wsrep_cluster_size Here the value 3 indicates the number of nodes presently connected to the cluster. wsrep_ready Here the value ON indicates that this node is connected to the cluster and able to handle transactions. On any database client, create a database and table then insert data: CREATE DATABASE galera; CREATE TABLE galera.test (id INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT, message TEXT) ENGINE=InnoDB; INSERT INTO galera.test (message) VALUES ("Hello, my dear cluster!"); INSERT INTO galera.test (message) VALUES ("Hello, again, cluster dear!"); On the database client for a different node, check that the data was replicated correctly. SELECT * FROM galera.test; +----+-----------------------------+ | id | message | +----+-----------------------------+ | 1 | Hello, my dear cluster! | | 2 | Hello, again, cluster dear! | +----+-----------------------------+ What the results given in the SELECT query indicate is that data you inserted into one node has replicated to another node on the cluster. This shows that the cluster now functions as a single distributed database instance. Data entered on any node replicates to all another nodes, where you can query and manipulate it as suits your needs.
Cluster Recovery To protect against power outages and similar catastrophic hardware failures that might kill all mysqld processes in your cluster, Galera Cluster nodes save the Primary Component to disk under the gvwstate.dat file, recording both the state of the Primary Component and the UUID's of the nodes connected to it. In the event of such outages, once all the referenced nodes achieve connectivity, the cluster recovers the Primary Component. This feature allows for: Automatic recovery from full cluster crashes, such as data center power outages; and, Graceful full cluster restarts, without the need for explicit bootstrapping of a new Primary Component. In the event that the write-set position differs between the nodes, the recovery process also requires a full state snapshot transfer. You can enable or disable this feature using the pc.recovery parameter. By default it is enabled. Understanding the Primary Component State When a node stores the Primary Component state to disk, it saves it as the gvwstate.dat file. The node creates and updates this file when the cluster forms or changes the Primary Component. This ensures that the node retains the latest Primary Component state that it was in. If the node loses connectivity or crashes, it retains this file as a reference. If the node shuts down graceful, it deletes the file. my_uuid: d3124bc8-1605-11e4-aa3d-ab44303c044a #vwbeg view_id: 3 0dae1307-1606-11e4-aa94-5255b1455aa0 12 bootstrap: 0 member: 0dae1307-1606-11e4-aa94-5255b1455aa0 1 member: 47bbe2e2-1606-11e4-8593-2a6d8335bc79 1 member: d3124bc8-1605-11e4-aa3d-ab44303c044a 1 #vwend The gvwstate.dat file divides into two parts: The Node Information section provides the node's UUID under the my_uuid field. The View Information section provides information on the node's view of the Primary Component. This information is organized between the #vwbeg and #vwend tags. The view_id field breaks into three parts. The first part indicates the view type, which always appears as 3, indicating the primary view. The second part provides a UUID for the view, which with the view sequence number altogether provides a unique identifier for the view. The bootstrap field displays whether or not the node bootstrapped. It does not effect the Primary Component recovery process. The member fields display the UUID's of nodes recorded as part of the Primary Component. You can find the gvwstate.dat file in the data directory for node's mysqld instance.
deleted_lines: <title>MySQL with Galera</title> <para>Rather than starting with a vanilla version of MySQL, and then adding Galera, you will want to install a version of MySQL patched for wsrep (Write Set REPlication) from <link xlink:href="https://launchpad.net/codership-mysql/0.7">https://launchpad.net/codership-mysql/0.7</link>. The wsrep API is suitable for configuring MySQL High Availability in OpenStack because it supports synchronous replication.</para> <para>Note that the installation requirements call for careful attention. Read the guide <link xlink:href="https://launchpadlibrarian.net/66669857/README-wsrep">https://launchpadlibrarian.net/66669857/README-wsrep</link> to ensure you follow all the required steps.</para> <orderedlist numeration="arabic" inheritnum="ignore" continuation="restarts"> <title>Installing Galera through a MySQL version patched for wsrep:</title> <listitem> <para>Download Galera from <link xlink:href="https://launchpad.net/galera/+download">https://launchpad.net/galera/+download</link>, and install the *.rpms or *.debs, which takes care of any dependencies that your system doesn't already have installed.</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Adjust the configuration:</para> <para>In the system-wide <filename>my.conf</filename> file, make sure <systemitem class="service">mysqld</systemitem> isn't bound to <literal>127.0.0.1</literal>, and that <filename>/etc/mysql/conf.d/</filename> is included. Typically you can find this file at <filename>/etc/my.cnf</filename>:</para> <programlisting language="ini">[mysqld] ... !includedir /etc/mysql/conf.d/ ... #bind-address = 127.0.0.1</programlisting> <para>When adding a new node, you must configure it with a MySQL account that can access the other nodes. The new node must be able to request a state snapshot from one of the existing nodes:</para> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Specify your MySQL account information in <filename>/etc/mysql/conf.d/wsrep.cnf</filename>: </para> <programlisting language="ini">wsrep_sst_auth=wsrep_sst:wspass</programlisting> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Connect as root and grant privileges to that user:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>mysql -e "SET wsrep_on=OFF; GRANT ALL ON *.* TO wsrep_sst@'%' IDENTIFIED BY 'wspass'";</userinput></screen> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Remove user accounts with empty user names because they cause problems:</para> <screen><prompt>$</prompt> <userinput>mysql -e "SET wsrep_on=OFF; DELETE FROM mysql.user WHERE user='';"</userinput></screen> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Set up certain mandatory configuration options within MySQL itself. These include:</para> <programlisting language="ini">query_cache_size=0default_storage_engine=innodbinnodb_doublewrite=1</programlisting> </listitem> <listitem> <para>Check that the nodes can access each other through the firewall. Depending on your environment, this might mean adjusting iptables, as in:</para> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iptables --insert RH-Firewall-1-INPUT 1 --proto tcp \ --source <my IP>/24 --destination <my IP>/32 --dport 3306 \ -j ACCEPT</userinput> <prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>iptables --insert RH-Firewall-1-INPUT 1 --proto tcp \ --source <my IP>/24 --destination <my IP>/32 --dport 4567 \ -j ACCEPT</userinput></screen> <para>This might also mean configuring any NAT firewall between nodes to allow direct connections. You might need to disable SELinux, or configure it to allow <systemitem class="service">mysqld</systemitem> to listen to sockets at unprivileged ports.</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <para>Now you're ready to create the cluster.</para> <section xml:id="_create_the_cluster"> <title>Create the cluster</title> <para>In creating a cluster, you first start a single instance, which creates the cluster. The rest of the MySQL instances then connect to that cluster:</para> <orderedlist numeration="arabic" inheritnum="ignore" continuation="restarts"> <title>An example of creating the cluster:</title> <listitem> <para>Start on the first node having IP address <literal>10.0.0.10</literal> by executing the command:</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service mysql start wsrep_cluster_address=gcomm://</userinput></screen> <orderedlist numeration="arabic" inheritnum="ignore" continuation="restarts"> <listitem> <para>Connect to that cluster on the rest of the nodes by referencing the address of that node, as in:</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <screen><prompt>#</prompt> <userinput>service mysql start wsrep_cluster_address=gcomm://10.0.0.10</userinput></screen> <para>You also have the option to set the <literal>wsrep_cluster_address</literal> in the <filename>/etc/mysql/conf.d/wsrep.cnf</filename> file, or within the client itself. (In fact, for some systems, such as MariaDB or Percona, this may be your only option.)</para> <orderedlist numeration="arabic" inheritnum="ignore" continuation="restarts"> <title>An example of checking the status of the cluster.</title> <listitem> <para>Open the MySQL client and check the status of the various parameters:</para> </listitem> </orderedlist> <screen><prompt>mysql></prompt> <userinput>SET GLOBAL wsrep_cluster_address='<cluster address string>';</userinput> <prompt>mysql></prompt> <userinput>SHOW STATUS LIKE 'wsrep%';</userinput></screen> <para>You should see a status that looks something like this:</para> <screen><prompt>mysql></prompt> <userinput>show status like 'wsrep%';</userinput> <computeroutput>+----------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | Variable_name | Value | +----------------------------+--------------------------------------+ | commit_message:
Put py34 first in the env order of tox

To solve the problem of "db type could not be determined" on py34
we have to run first the py34 env to, then, run py27. This patch
puts py34 first on the tox.ini list of envs to avoid this problem
to happen.

Change-Id: Ib9e09706fd915c4f28910fe68543764ca51d8aad
Closes-bug: #1489059
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/08/254108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: envlist = py34,py27,py27dj18,pep8,releasenotes

commit_message:
Remove docker version pinning for vagrant envs

Kolla now has its own docker ansible module which doesn't require
specific docker version.

Also, add requirement for ansible <2, and stop using NL mirror for
epel.

Change-Id: I743c51c2d6b7f6af0aa4038e1081066b36e36fa1
Partially-Implements: blueprint kolla-docker-module

commit_message:
Documentation improvements.

The version changes in docker are needed to support named volumes
which are replacing data containers in our implementation. Docker
is no unblocked upstream for us thanks to our new kolla_docker
module so I removed the cap on that as well.

Change-Id: I847979b9f7c9e42a55273b5ee926a4aff19a7bec
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla refs/changes/55/263055/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Ubuntu: For Ubuntu based systems where Docker is used it is recommended to use the latest available lts kernel. The latest lts kernel available is the wily kernel (version 4.2). While all kernels should work for Docker, some older kernels may have issues with some of the different Docker backends such as AUFS and OverlayFS. In order to update kernel in Ubuntu 14.04 LTS to 4.2, run: sudo apt-get install linux-image-generic-lts-wilyDocker 1.9.0 none On target nodes Docker Python 1.6.0 none On target nodesDocker 1.8.3 and later are incompatible with Kolla Liberty. Versions greater than 1.8.2 are functional with master branch (Mitaka). If the version installed is 1.8.3 or later and you are running Liberty, downgrade using these commands:
deleted_lines: Ubuntu: For Ubuntu based systems where Docker is used, do not use AUFS when starting Docker daemon, unless running Ubuntu uses 3.19 kernel or above. AUFS requires CONFIG\_AUFS\_XATTR=y set when building the kernel. On Ubuntu, versions prior to 3.19 did not set this flag to be compatible with Docker. In order to update kernel in Ubuntu 14.04 LTS to 3.19, run: sudo apt-get install linux-image-generic-lts-vivid If unable to upgrade the kernel, the Kolla community recommends using a different storage backend such as btrfs when running Docker daemon.Docker 1.8.2 1.8.2 On target nodes Docker Python 1.2.0 none On target nodesDocker 1.8.3 and later are incompatible with Kolla. If the version installed is 1.8.3 or later, consider downgrading by using these commands:

added_lines: "PO-Revision-Date: 2016-01-03 11:46+0000\n"msgid "" "Interacts directly with the Shared File Systems service and processes such " "as the manila-scheduler. It also interacts with these processes through a " "message queue. The manila-share service responds to read and write requests " "sent to the Shared File Systems service to maintain state. It can interact " "with a variety of storage providers through a driver architecture." msgstr "" "공유 파일 시스템 서비스와 직접 상호작용하며, manila-scheduler와 동일한 처리" "를 합니다. 메시지 큐를 통해 다른 프로세스들과 상호 작용합니다. manila-share " "서비스는 maintain 상태인 공유 파일 시스템 서비스에서 보낸 읽고 쓰는 요청에 대" "해 응답합니다. 드라이버 아키텍처를 통해 다양한 스토리지 프로바이더를 적용할 " "수 있습니다." msgid "Routes information between the Shared File Systems processes." msgstr "공유 파일 시스템 프로세스간 정보를 전달합니다." "Selects the optimal storage provider node on which to create the share. A " "similar component to the cinder-scheduler." msgstr "" "공유 생성하는데 최적의 스토리지 프로바이더 노드를 선택합니다. cinder-" "scheduler와 유사한 구성요소입니다." msgid ""msgid "manila-scheduler daemon" msgstr "manila-scheduler 데몬"
